objdescid.compdate: c. 1790-93The date is based on stylistic considerations.

objinfo.medium: water color and pen and ink over pencil

provenance.name: Folger Shakespeare Library
provenance.note: Possibly the work acquired at an unknown time by Samuel Prince and sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 11 Dec. 1865, lot 277, titled "Oberon" (£1.3s. to "Willis," probably a dealer); G. E. Taylor by 1877; Brenda G. Warr, sold from her collection Sotheby's, 17 Dec. 1928, lot 137 (£65 to the dealer Gabriel Wells acting for Henry Clay Folger and his wife Emily Jordan Folger); given to the Folger Shakespeare Library upon its founding in 1932.

desc.objtitle:
Oberon and Titania, Preceded by Puck,
Object 1 (Butlin 246.1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Five figures fly or hover against a starry sky in this illustration of Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. The rightmost figure flies right but turns to face forward with both arms bent and raised, with palms facing forward and fingers spread. The figure is male with short, perhaps curly hair and an open mouth. He may be speaking and leading the other figures to the right. He wears a shirt, breeches, and a red cape or cloak; a sword is visible against his left hip. Both legs are bent slightly with his right leg extended backward at left. He is likely Puck, the sprite assistant to Oberon, King of the Fairies. In the center of the composition, a pair of figures fly to the right or hover. They are likely Oberon and Titania, the king and queen of the Fairies in the play. Titania, the female figure at right, has long hair and wears a gown. Although she faces right, she turns forward perhaps to look toward her companion. Her left arm is straight and by her side. Her legs are together and extended horizontally at left. To her left, a male figure, likely Oberon, faces right. He has long hair and a beard and wears a crown, long gown, and red cape or cloak. With his right arm, which is bent and at his side, he holds a scepter. His left arm may be bent by his side, perhaps under his cape; he may hold an orb(?) with this hand in front of his lower torso. Both legs are together and extended to the left. To the left of this pair, two small gowned female figures, probably fairies, also fly right and hold the trains of the king and queen's gowns with raised, bent arms. The figure at right has long hair and may wear a garland on her head. She turns her head to look left, likely toward her companion, who also has long hair and wears a headband or garland on her head. Both figures extend their legs to the left. Below the five figures, there appears to be an area of dark ground or earth, and behind them, dark sky with stars, suggesting the time is night, perhaps at the conclusion of the play when Oberon and Titania lead the Fairies away and Puck concludes: "So good night unto you all./ Give me your hands, if we be friends,/ And Robin shall restore amends." (Act 5, Scene 1, 453-455).

component.illusobjdesc: Five figures fly or hover against a starry sky in this illustration of Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. Leading the procession, the rightmost figure flies right but turns to face forward with both arms bent and raised, with palms facing forward and fingers spread. The figure is male with short, perhaps curly hair and an open mouth. He may be speaking and leading the other figures to the right. He wears a shirt, breeches, and a red cape or cloak; a sword is visible against his left hip. Both legs are bent slightly with his right leg extended backward at left. He is likely Puck, also called Robin Goodfellow, the sprite assistant to Oberon, king of the Fairies.
The rightmost figure in the scene, likely Puck, wears a downward-pointing sword against his left hip.

Five figures fly or hover against a starry sky in this illustration of Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. In the center of the composition, a pair of figures fly to the right or hover. They are likely Oberon and Titania, the king and queen of the Fairies in the play. Titania, the female figure at right, has long hair and wears a gown with a belt. She may wear a blue cloak, as evinced by the blue cloth held by the small figure to the left and a slender arc of blue below and to the right of Titania's left hip. Although she faces right, she turns forward, perhaps even slightly left to look toward her companion. Her left arm is straight and by her side. Her legs are together and extended horizontally at left.

Five figures fly or hover against a starry sky in this illustration of Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. In the center of the composition, a pair of figures fly to the right or hover. They are likely Oberon and Titania, the king and queen of the Fairies in the play. At left, Oberon faces right. He has long hair and a beard and wears a crown, long gown, and red cape or cloak. With his right arm, which is bent and at his side, he holds a scepter. His left arm may be bent by his side, perhaps under his cape or cloak; he may hold an orb(?) with this hand in front of his lower torso. Both legs are together and extended to the left.

The central male figure in this scene, Oberon, holds a scepter in his right hand and may hold an orb(?) in his left hand, held near his lower torso. These, along with his crown, likely attest to his status as king of the Fairies.

Near the left side of the design, two small gowned female figures, probably fairies, fly right and hold the trains of the king and queen's gowns with raised, bent arms. Their bodies are almost horizontal. The figure at right has long hair and may wear a garland on her head. She turns her head to look left, likely toward her companion. Both figures extend their legs to the left.

Near the left side of the design, two small gowned female figures, probably fairies, fly right and hold the trains of the king and queen's gowns with raised, bent arms. Their bodies are almost horizontal. The figure at left has long hair and wears a headband or garland. She appears to look toward her companion. Both figures extend their legs to the left.
There appears to be an area of dark ground or earth along the bottom edge of the design above which the five figures fly or hover.

Behind the five flying figures, there is dark sky with stars, suggesting the time is night, perhaps at the conclusion of the play when Oberon and Titania lead the Fairies away and Puck concludes: "So good night unto you all./ Give me your hands, if we be friends,/ And Robin shall restore amends." (Act 5, Scene 1, 453-455).
